facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 941-946 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 941. 946 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment dated February 22, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 121 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment dated February 22, 1961 of Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 121 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment dated February 22, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 121 of 1956. N. Rajagopal Sastri, R. H. Dhebar and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in all the appeals . V. Viswanatha Sastri, K. Rajendra Chaudhuri and K. R. Chaudhuri, for the respondent  in all the appeals .

facts.text: Andhra Chamber of Commerce is a company incorporated under Indian Companies Act 7 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Chamber of Commerce-hereinafter called the assessees a Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act 7 of 1913. The assessee was permitted under S. 26 of the Act to omit the word Limited from its name by order of the Government of Madras.

facts.text: Assessee permitted under S. 26 to omit word 'Limited' from name by Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was permitted under S. 26 of the Act to omit the word Limited from its name by order of the Government of Madras. The following are the principal objects of the Memorandum of Association of the assessee To promote and protect trade, companymerce and industries of India, in the Province of Madras and in particular in the Andhra companyntry.

facts.text: Principal objects: To promote and protect trade, commerce and industries of India, in Province of Madras and particularly Andhra country.

anchor.surface_text: The following are the principal objects of the Memorandum of Association of the assessee To promote and protect trade, companymerce and industries of India, in the Province of Madras and in particular in the Andhra companyntry. To aid, stimulate and promote the development of trade, companymerce and industries in India, or any part thereof with capital principally provided by Indians or under the management of Indians.

facts.text: Cl. 4 of Memorandum: income and property applied solely towards promotion of objects, no portion paid as dividends to members.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 4 of the Memorandum of Association it was provided that the income and property of the assessee shall be applied solely towards the promotion of its objects as set forth therein and numberportion thereof shall be paid or transferred, directly or indirectly, by way of dividends, bonuses or otherwise howsoever by way of profit to its members.

facts.text: Assessee purchased building on December 2, 1944 and made substantial alterations, additions and improvements.

anchor.surface_text: On December 2, 1944 the assessee purchased a building and made substantial alterations, additions and improvements therein. The assessee then moved its offices into that building on May 14, 1947 and let out to tenants the portion number required for its use.

facts.text: Assessee moved offices into building on May 14, 1947 and let out portions not required.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then moved its offices into that building on May 14, 1947 and let out to tenants the portion number required for its use. The income of the assessee is obtained from subscriptions and donations companylected from its members and rent received from the building.

facts.text: Income from subscriptions, donations from members and rent from building.

anchor.surface_text: The income of the assessee is obtained from subscriptions and donations companylected from its members and rent received from the building. facts.text: ITO assessed income from property on net annual value without set-off of excess expenditure for six years.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment before the Second Additional Income-tax Officer, City Circle 1, Madras, it was companytended that Sup./65-11 the annual value of the building was number assessable in its hands as the assessee was a charitable institution within the meaning of s. 4 3   i  of the Income-tax Act, 1922. ... The Income- tax Officer rejected the companytentions of the assessee and assessed its income from property on the basis of net annual value in the six assessment years without debiting the -expenditure in excess of income  other than rent  against the net annual value.

facts.text: Assessee contended before ITO: building income exempt as charitable under S.4(3)(i), alternatively set off excess expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment before the Second Additional Income-tax Officer, City Circle 1, Madras, it was companytended that Sup./65-11 the annual value of the building was number assessable in its hands as the assessee was a charitable institution within the meaning of s. 4 3   i  of the Income-tax Act, 1922. In the alternative, it was companytended that the excess of expenditure over income should be set off against such income if the annual value is held assess,able.

facts.text: AAC rejected exemption under S.4(3)(i) and alternative set-off.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commis- sioner against all the orders of assessments. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the assessee number being a charitable institution the income in question was number exempt under s. 4 3   i . He also rejected the alternative companytention, for in his view, there was numberspecific profit- making activity of the assessee the loss from which companyld be set off against its other income.

facts.text: ITAT held assessee not exempt under S.4(3)(i) as activities for benefit of members.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals were then taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribu- nal. The Tribunal held that the assessee was number exempt within the meaning of s. 4 3   i  from liability to pay income-tax, because the activities of the assessee were intended for the benefit primarily of its members and embraced only companylective action on behalf of all its companystituent members which companyld number be said to be the result of any trade or business or vocation carried on by it.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court at instance of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the Tribunal referred the following questions to the High Court Whether the aforesaid income from property owned by the assessee is exempt under S. 4  3   i  for the aforesaid six years of assessment ? If the answer to the above question is in the negative, whether the activities of the assessee amount to a trade or business, the profit or loss from which is assessable under S. 10 ?

facts.text: High Court answered first question affirmatively (exempt), no formal answer on second.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and did number record a formal answer on the second question. Against the order of the High Court, these appeals are preferred by the -Commissioner of Income-tax, with certificate granted by the High Court under S. 66A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appeals preferred by Commissioner with certificate under S.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the High Court, these appeals are preferred by the -Commissioner of Income-tax, with certificate granted by the High Court under S. 66A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act. We are companycerned in this group of appeals with the assess- ment of income of the assessee in the years 1948-49 to 1954- with the omission of the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: Assessments concerned: 1948-49 to 1954-55 except 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this group of appeals with the assess- ment of income of the assessee in the years 1948-49 to 1954- with the omission of the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee's objects are of general public utility, charitable under S.4(3)(i).

Such an object must be regarded as purely ancillary or subsidiary and number the primary object.

holdings.text: The building which the assessee owns is by virtue of cl. 4 of the Memorandum of Association held under a legal obligation to apply its income to purposes specified in the Memorandum of Association.

anchor.surface_text: The building which the assessee owns is by virtue of cl. 4 of the Memorandum of Association held under a legal obligation to apply its income to purposes specified in the Memorandum of Association. It is not the case of the assessee that the objects of incorporation are relief of the poor,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 4 of MoA mandates that income and property be applied solely to promotion of objects set forth therein, with no distribution to members, creating legal obligation equivalent to trust.

holdings.text: In the promotion of trade, commerce and industries of India the public is vitally interested and if by the activities of the assessee that object is achieved, it would be within the meaning of S. 4 3   1  of the Act an advancement of an object of general public utility.

anchor.surface_text: In the promotion of trade, commerce and industries of India the public is vitally interested and if by the activities of the assessee that object is achieved, it would be within the meaning of S. 4 3   1  of the Act an advancement of an object of general public utility. In enacting the last paragraph of S. 4 3  the legislature has used language of great amplitude.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principal objects to promote/protect trade, commerce, industries benefit entire community leading to economic prosperity; inclusive definition of charitable purpose covers general public utility.

holdings.text: These objects are not vague or indefinite as objects of general public utility.

anchor.surface_text: These objects are number vague or inde-  1  6 I.T.R. 427. finite as objects of general public utility. An object of general public utility, such as promotion, protection, aiding and stimulation of trade, commerce and industries need number, to be valid specify the modus or the steps by which the objects may be achieved or secured.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotion/protection of trade etc. specific enough; courts can administer without detailed modus operandi; distinguishes vague cases like 'dharam'.

holdings.text: By the achievement of these objects, it is not intended to serve merely the interests of the members of the assessee. Advancement or promotion of trade, commerce and industry leading to economic prosperity enures for the benefit of the entire community.

anchor.surface_text: By the achievement of these objects, it is number intended to serve merely the interests of the members of the assessee. Advancement or promotion of trade, commerce and industry leading to economic prosperity enures for the benefit of the entire community. That prosperity would be shared also by those who engage in trade, commerce and industry but on that account the purpose is number rendered any the less an object of general public utility.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incidental benefits to members/traders do not disqualify; wide open membership; analogies to Yorkshire Agricultural Society and Institution of Civil Engineers.

holdings.text: Such an object must be regarded as purely ancillary or subsidiary and not the primary object.

anchor.surface_text: Such an object must be regarded as purely ancillary or subsidiary and number the primary object. - The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.3(g) on urging/opposing legislation incidental to primary trade promotion objects; analogies to Tribune trust and All India Spinners Association.

holdings.text: It is common ground that by the amendment, no alteration which has a material bearing on the question to be decided in these appeals has been made.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that by the amendment, numberalteration which has a material bearing on the question to be decided in these appeals has been made. Income from property qualifies for exemption under S. 4 3  if two conditions coexist  i  the property is held under trust or other legal obligation and  ii  it is so held wholly or in part

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment by Act 25 of 1953 amalgamated clauses but did not materially alter provision relevant to case.

holdings.text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings on legal obligation, charitable public utility objects, rejection of vagueness/members/political contentions lead to exemption under S.4(3)(i).

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Yorkshire Agricultural Society 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Yorkshire Agricultural Society 1  an association called the Yorkshire Agricultural Society was formed with the object of holding annual meetings for the exhibition of farming stock, implements etc., and for the general promotion of agriculture.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Yorkshire Agricultural Society
precedents.cited_proposition: Society promoting agriculture is charitable notwithstanding incidental benefits to members
precedents.cited_holding: Society was established for a charitable purpose and that purpose continued notwithstanding the incidental benefits enjoyed by members

precedents.cited_holding: Institution was established for charitable purposes only, notwithstanding advantage to members incidental
